name: Geneva
fun_fact: Fun fact: Geneva is Switzerland's most international city and earned the title of European Region of Gastronomy in 2019. With 13 Michelin-starred establishments and proximity to France and Italy, Geneva offers an 'amazing culinary world tour' from haute cuisine to authentic mountain chalets - all while being home to major international organizations.

hero_dishes.name: Raclette
hero_dishes.description: Semi-hard cheese melted and scraped onto boiled potatoes, served with pickled onions, cornichons, and charcuterie. The cheese is heated until bubbling and served immediately.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Traditional Alpine dish where shepherds would melt cheese by the fire. The name comes from the French 'racler' (to scrape). Geneva's restaurants maintain this rustic tradition in cozy chalet settings.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Auberge de Savi√®se, L'Edelweiss Restaurant, La Cave Valaisanne (all specialize in traditional Swiss Alpine dishes)

hero_dishes.name: Filets de Perche (Lake Perch Fillets)
hero_dishes.description: Fresh perch fillets from Lake Geneva, lightly breaded and pan-fried, typically served with frites and lemon. A local specialty showcasing Geneva's lakeside location.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Taking advantage of Geneva's position on Lake Geneva (Lac L√©man), this dish represents the city's connection to its waters and sustainable local fishing traditions.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Lakefront restaurants and traditional Swiss establishments throughout Geneva

signature_drinks.name: Swiss White Wine (Geneva Region)
signature_drinks.description: Local wines from Geneva's vineyards, particularly Chasselas whites. Geneva has a strong 'locavore' wine culture with wines from Geneva or French-speaking Switzerland.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Paired with fondue (white wine is traditional) or enjoyed with lake perch. Many restaurants feature local Geneva wines as part of the 'field to plate' movement.

food_culture_notes: Fondue is seasonal - typically not served May to October (too warm!)
Reservations are nearly impossible without booking ahead, especially for evening fondue at popular spots like La Buvette des Bains
Geneva's cuisine is a 'harmonious blend of Swiss traditions, French finesse, and international diversity'
Strong focus on quality ingredients, sustainability, and seasonality - part of the 'locavore' movement
The city offers culinary world tours: Mexican, Peruvian, Japanese, Chinese, Lebanese, Indian, Moroccan cuisine all highly accessible
